articles.author: Frederik Dohr
articles.description:
We’re fans of Custom Elements around here. Their design makes them particularly amenable to lazy loading, which can be a boon for performance.
Inspired by a colleague’s experiments, I recently set about writing a simple auto-loader: Whenever a custom …
An Approach to Lazy Loading Custom Elements originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: An Approach to Lazy Loading Custom Elements

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description:
It’s a question I hear asked quite often: Is it possible to create shadows from gradients instead of solid colors? There is no specific CSS property that does this (believe me, I’ve looked) and any blog post you find about …
Different Ways to Get CSS Gradient Shadows originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Different Ways to Get CSS Gradient Shadows

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Every now and then, a one blog post is published and it spurs a reaction or response in others that are, in turn, published as blogs posts, and a theme starts to emerge. That’s what happened this past week and …
Healthcare, Selling Lemons, and the Price of Developer Experience originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Healthcare, Selling Lemons, and the Price of Developer Experience

articles.author: Saleh Mubashar
articles.description: We often think of background images as texture or something that provides contrast for legible content — in other words, not really content. If it was content, you’d probably reach for an anyway, accessibility and whatnot. But there are … Moving Backgrounds originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Geez, leave it to Patrick Brosset to talk CSS performance in the most approachable and practical way possible. Not that CSS is always what’s gunking up the speed, or even the lowest hanging fruit when it comes to improving …
The truth about CSS selector performance originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: The truth about CSS selector performance

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
I used to have this boss who loved, loved, loved, loved to emphasize words. This was way back before we used a WYSIWYG editors and I’d have to handcode that crap.

articles.description:
Do you know that kind of effect where someone’s head is poking through a circle or hole? The famous Porky Pig animation where he waves goodbye while popping out of a series of red rings is the perfect example, and …
A Fancy Hover Effect For Your Avatar originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: Adam Rackis
articles.description:
My previous post was a broad overview of SvelteKit where we saw what a great tool it is for web development. This post will fork off what we did there and dive into every developer’s favorite topic: caching. So, …
Caching Data in SvelteKit originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s get ready for March with some fresh wallpapers! Designed with love by the community for the community, the wallpaper designs in this collection are available in versions with and without a calendar. Enjoy!
articles.title: Daydreaming In March (2023 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Mikołaj Dobrucki)
articles.description: In the ever-evolving design tools landscape, it can be difficult to keep up with the latest and greatest. In this article, we’ll take a closer look at Penpot, the first design and prototyping tool that’s fully open-source and based on open web standards, making it an ideal choice for both designers and developers.
articles.title: Meet Penpot, An Open-Source Design Platform Made For Designers And Developers Alike

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sandrina Pereira)
articles.description: Each time we build a field validation from scratch, accessibility doesn’t come out of the box. In this guide, Sandrina breaks down what we need to take into consideration, so that nobody gets stuck on an inaccessible invalid field.
articles.title: A Guide To Accessible Form Validation

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Brand new conference on design & UX, for designers and UI engineers who love the web. On design systems, usability, product design and complex UIs. That’s SmashingConf Antwerp, taking place in magical Bourla on October 9–11, 2023.
articles.title: Chocolate, Waffles And Fries: Meet SmashingConf Antwerp 2023 🇧🇪

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Manuel Schröder)
articles.description: Let’s see how to achieve phenomenal web performance and great developer experience with Astro and a headless CMS, resulting in the best possible experience for users, developers and content creators alike.
articles.title: Building Future-Proof High-Performance Websites With Astro Islands And Headless CMS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Facundo Giuliani & Arisa Fukuzaki)
articles.description: This article will show you the impact of internationalization, its fundamental logic, how to approach it with Remix, and optionally, how to manage it more conveniently using a headless CMS.
articles.title: Getting Internationalization (i18n) Right With Remix And Headless CMS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode of the Smashing Podcast, we ask what’s the key to a great keyboard? Is this essential part of our daily toolkit easily overlooked? Vitaly Friedman talks to expert Marcin Wichary to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 57 With Marcin Wichary: What’s The Key To A Great Keyboard?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Daniel Yuschick)
articles.description: An accessible product can be daunting to build as there’s so much nuance and technical depth to consider. In this article, Daniel Yuschick demonstrates three keys for approaching and developing accessible content without leaving you lost in the weeds.
articles.title: Keys To An Accessibility Mindset

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sonja Weckenmann)
articles.description: Most carousels come along with usability and accessibility issues. To avoid these issues, this article addresses step-by-step design considerations as well as semantic requirements for carousels to be accessible. It is intended to create an in-depth understanding of the implementation and its impact on users.
articles.title: A Step-By-Step Guide To Building Accessible Carousels

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Scanlon)
articles.description: SVG `` provides a way to define how an element moves along a motion path. In this article, Paul Scanlon shares an idea of how to use it by animating race cars in an infinite loop as easy as one-two-three!
articles.title: Putting Gears In Motion: Animating Cars With HTML And SVG

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Chiara Aliotta)
articles.description: How to apply powerful storytelling to design a compelling and memorable digital experience on a landing page. A case study of the [Smart Interface Design Patterns landing page](https://smart-interface-design-patterns.com/).
articles.title: Five Steps To Design Your Product With Powerful Storytelling

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kirill Myshkin)
articles.description: In the first part of the series, Kirill Myshkin covers some aspects of JavaScript that help bring objects closer to primitive values, which allow benefiting from common language features that aren’t usually associated with an object, like comparisons and arithmetic operators.
articles.title: Discovering Primitive Objects In JavaScript (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Hristo Chakarov)
articles.description: With so many image editing services available nowadays, it’s good to have one good solution that is applicable for all websites and web apps that need to provide image editing as a feature. Hristo Chakarov explains how Pixo Editor’s easy integration (just a few JavaScript lines) and rich API can save your time and improve your end users’ workflow.
articles.title: Picture Perfect: Meet Pixo, A Photo Editor For Your End Users

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Budd)
articles.description: In this article, Andy Budd shares his way of requesting feedback: rather than sharing a linear case study that explains every design revision, the first thing to do would be to better frame the problem.
articles.title: How Designers Should Ask For (And Receive) High-Quality Feedback

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode of the Smashing Podcast we ask how has the design industry changed? Is technology making our work easier? Vitaly Friedman talks to veteran designer Veerle Pieters to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 56 With Veerle Pieters: How Has The Design Industry Changed?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Jennifer Brehm)
articles.description: Web development, especially what you can do with CSS, has become increasingly complex. With the added capabilities of CSS Grid, it is now possible to achieve layouts that look like they were laid out by hand. Let’s tackle a practical example of how to do something like that.
articles.title: How To Build A Magazine Layout With CSS Grid Areas

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Podcasts are a fantastic opportunity to get up close with the people who know their craft. In this post, we compiled podcasts that are bound to provide valuable insights into UX and new perspectives on the field. Perfect for a short coffee break or a long commute.
articles.title: UX Podcasts For Designers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: Lightsail provides all the power we need to host our websites, as we are used to from AWS, but making it way easier than ever before. In this article, Leonardo Losoviz explores how to launch a WordPress site in Lightsail in a quick and easy way.
articles.title: How To Host A WordPress Site On Amazon Lightsail

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Atila Fassina)
articles.description: The new App Directory architecture has been the main character of the recent Next.js release, which keeps bringing up many questions. In this article, Atila Fassina explores the advantages and pitfalls of this new strategy and reflects on whether you should use it in production now or not.
articles.title: Understanding App Directory Architecture In Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Do you need a little inspiration boost? Well, then our new batch of desktop wallpapers is for you. Designed by artists and designers from across the globe, they come in versions with and without a calendar for February 2023.
articles.title: The Magic Of February (2023 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Throughout a customer journey (particularly in B2B), there will be interactions that are primarily between two people rather than a human and an interface. In this article, Paul Boag explains why you cannot improve the user experience without considering the entirety of the UX journey.
articles.title: How B2B Sales Help Us Understand Our Role As UX Designers Better

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: Developers often feel discouraged from editing SVG markup and experimenting with SVG animations, thinking it’s a significant time investment or they need to use a complex animation library to do so. In this article, Adrian showcases his favorite tricks, which make the process streamlined and fun.
articles.title: Easy SVG Customization And Animation: A Practical Guide

articles.author: Dapo Adedire
articles.description: JavaScript, like most programming languages, was initially used for small tasks. But as its popularity grew, so did the amount of code that needed to be written.  Having a large amount of code in a single file can be problematic, so it's helpful to split the code into multiple
articles.title: JavaScript Modules – How to Create, Import, and Export a Module in JS

articles.author: Tomer Ben Rachel
articles.description: We’ve all seen it. We’ve all done it. Ain’t nothing like good ol’ tabs to organize content in a complex application. So how do we go about creating a tab layout in Jetpack Compose?  In this tutorial, we’ll go over all of the basics, but also show some things
articles.title: How to Create Tabs in Jetpack Compose

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: AlphaZero is a game-playing algorithm that uses artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques to learn how to play board games at a superhuman level. We just published a machine learning course on the freeCodeCamp.org channel that will teach you how  to build AlphaZero from scratch. Robert Förster created this course.
articles.title: Code an AlphaZero Machine Learning Algorithm to Play Games

articles.author: Joel Olawanle
articles.description: When working with JavaScript, you might need to replace a string or substring with a new one. For example, you might want to replace a certain string (like "color” — American English) or substring in a larger text or document with a different string (“colour” — British English). You may
articles.title: JavaScript Replace – How to Replace a String or Substring in JS

articles.author: Sophia Iroegbu
articles.description: If you're a developer, choosing the proper UI framework can be tough. This is partly because there are so many options to choose from, each with its strengths and weaknesses.  In this guide, I will discuss the differences between two popular frameworks: Tailwind CSS and NextUI.  Tailwind CSS
articles.title: TailwindCSS vs NextUI – How to Choose a UI Framework

articles.author: Manish Shivanandhan
articles.description: Flutter is a mobile app development framework from Google that lets you build beautiful, high-performance iOS and Android applications.  In this article, let’s look at what Flutter is and how to work with it. What is Flutter? Flutter is an open-source mobile application development framework created by Google. It
articles.title: How to Build Mobile Apps with Flutter

articles.author: Daniel Iwugo
articles.description: Let’s play a lovely game of hide your malware in plain sight. 🐴 Malicious hackers look for all kinds of underhanded tricks to make everyday users victims as a result of common mistakes. They might get someone to click the wrong link, open the wrong website, or execute the wrong
articles.title: What is RTLO in Hacking? How to Use Right-to-Left Override and Defend Against it

articles.author: Ihechikara Vincent Abba
articles.description: When working on a project with a team or by yourself, it's important to track changes in the code base through version control.  Git provides you with different commands for tracking file changes. These commands will enable you to collaborate with other developers, access file history, manage code, and
articles.title: Git Revert – How to Reset a File or Commit

articles.author: Shittu Olumide
articles.description: A dictionary in Python is a group of unordered items, each of which has a unique set of keys and values.  Any immutable data type, such as a string, number, or tuple, can be used as the key. It serves as an exclusive identifier for the value in the
articles.title: Adding to Dict in Python – How to Append to a Dictionary

articles.author: Sonya Moisset
articles.description: Christine Peterson coined the term "Open Source software" or OSS in 1998. It refers to software that is freely available for anyone to use, modify, and distribute.  The source code of OSS is openly available and anyone can modify it who has the necessary technical skills. This allows for
articles.title: Open Source Software Security Handbook – Best Practices for Securing Your Projects
